content:
I suggest you have a look at the account settings. Specifically at server settings. There you will find the settings for all of the things you have mentioned unless your account is IMAP and not POP.

Note well the server Type at the first entry on the image below of a POP account server settings page. If it is IMAP that is the type of account you have configured.
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
I do not think you get this support process. This is a public forum offering peer support for software installed on your computer (Thunderbird)

We can work with you to try and work out why you are not receiving mails, but no one can check anything on your computer but you.

See https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/cannot-receive-messages
creator: MattAuSupport

content: just reinstall Thunderbird from thunderbird.net. That should clear the failed update with a working version.

content: Update to the above- finally found the correct setting: View- Message body as- Original HTML.

content:
There is no such thing as a 'thunderbird email account'. If you do have a Gmail account, then obviously Google will 'chase' you for Google account password.

Also see https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/thunderbird-faq#w_what-is-my-thunderbird-email-address

content: Is the folder threaded? Click alt key if menu bar not visible. then, click view>sort by and see if threaded is ticked.
creator: davidsk

content: - exit thunderbird first - very important - copy c:\users\<yourid>\appdata\roaming\thunderbird to the USB stick - install thunderbird on other PC and then exit. - copy the thunderbird folder on usb stick to c:\users\<yourid>\appdata\roaming (this will overwrite existing files, so you will be prompted)
creator: davidsk

content: Seeing a screenshot may be helpful. Without that, check that view>headers is 'normal' and that view.message body as is 'original HTML'. If you do not have the menu bar set, click the alt key so that the view options are visible.
creator: davidsk

content: it seems that HTML is not being properly processed. I suggest - exit thunderbird - go to thunderbird.net and download a fresh copy - install the download over the current installation -
creator: davidsk

content: WAIT! before doing that, highlight the inbox, rightclick, select properties, and then click 'repair' = that often works
creator: davidsk

content: -click alt key to see menu bar if it's not visible - then, click view>layout and tick 'message list header' - then, lick the little icon to the right of the 'quick filter' button and select 'table view'

content: If you're sending in HTML, the composition bar allows you to select specific text and change color for just the selected words and the menu composition bar also allows you to set font for the entire message. If someone writes to you with colored font, thunderbird will show it.
creator: davidsk

content:
Thanks but that does not work. I have tried it. I cannot set or use colors either for the entire composition or a selection of it.

Also, Thunderbird does not show the sender's colors. It will show the sender's bolding, but not colors.
creator: carlosperdue

content: Please be very specific. What does not work? Is it that your composition bar in compose window doesn't show color? That is a default feature of thunderbird. If you do not see the HTML composition bar, that indicates you have Thunderbird set in plain text mode. How do you know the message received is in color?
creator: davidsk

content:
See composition screen below. Highlighting and selecting color does not work. It goes right back to black.

Thunderbird does not show the sender's colors. It will show the sender's bolding, but not colors.

Attached is an outgoing test email sent from protonmail webmail. The first string is bolded. The second string of letters is red tex.

The next attachment is that incoming email which Thunderbird shows as black only, no red. It does show the bolding.

I do not have anything set as text only as far as I know.
